conclusion: Determine the refractive index of the prism and the distance between points P and C.
The ray enters the prism at point M with an incident angle of 60 degrees.
Using Snell's Law, derive the equation sin 60 degrees = n sin theta.
Substitute sin 60 degrees = sqrt(3)/2 into the equation to get sqrt(3)/2 = n sin theta (Equation 1).
At point N, the ray undergoes total internal reflection on the BC side.
For total internal reflection, the angle of incidence at N must satisfy sin phi >= 1/n.
The refracted angle theta at M is equal to the angle of incidence phi at N due to symmetry, hence sin theta >= 1/n (Equation 2).
The square prism has side length a, and M is the midpoint of AB, so the distance from M to B is a/2.
The refracted ray travels diagonally from M to N and then reflects to P.
Using trigonometry, the refracted ray makes an angle theta with the normal at M, and travels a horizontal distance a/2 and a vertical distance a from M to N.
After total internal reflection at N, the ray exits the prism at P on the CD side.
The distance PC is proportional to the refracted angle theta, hence PC = a tan theta.
Solve for n using Equation 1: sin theta = sqrt(3)/(2n).
Substitute sin theta = sqrt(3)/(2n) into Equation 2: sqrt(3)/(2n) >= 1/n.
Simplify the inequality to get sqrt(3) >= 2.
